articles.headline: Tea Party Aims at Incumbents, but Falls Short
articles.snippet: The Tea Party has nudged Republicans to the right in Congress, but falls short when it comes to recruiting good challengers to take out incumbents.
articles.abstract: The Tea Party has nudged Republicans to the right in Congress, but falls short when it comes to recruiting good challengers to take out incumbents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, ought to be a prime target for a Tea Party challenge. He helped write the Senate overhaul of immigration laws that provided for a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants, backed President Obama’s Supreme Court nominees and expressed a willingness to raise taxes as part of a larger deal to address the nation’s fiscal health — all perilous positions in a deeply conservative state.

articles.headline: Dispute Over Leave Agitated Ft. Hood Soldier Before Shooting
articles.snippet: Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez, who shot almost 20 fellow soldiers, had been denied leave by his superiors, a law enforcement official said.
articles.abstract: Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez, who shot almost 20 fellow soldiers, had been denied leave by his superiors, a law enforcement official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — The Army specialist at Fort Hood who killed three and wounded 16 of his fellow soldiers on Wednesday had an angry dispute over a leave request shortly before the shooting rampage, a law enforcement official said Friday.

articles.headline: A Bold Bid to Combat a Crisis in Legal Education
articles.snippet: Brooklyn Law School said it would cut tuition and abandon what has become a widespread obsession with climbing the ladder of national law school rankings.
articles.abstract: Brooklyn Law School said it would cut tuition and abandon what has become a widespread obsession with climbing the ladder of national law school rankings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brooklyn Law School is hardly alone in facing a crisis in legal education. Five law schools have closed in the last two years, more than at any other time in American history.

articles.headline: Ruling Spurs Rush for Cash in Both Parties
articles.snippet: Fund-raisers are focusing on a group of 500 to 700 donors in both parties who appear to have maxed out their contributions or come close to a cap struck down by the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: Fund-raisers are focusing on a group of 500 to 700 donors in both parties who appear to have maxed out their contributions or come close to a cap struck down by the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader in the House, wasted little time on Thursday blasting the Supreme Court’s latest decision freeing donors to spend more money on campaigns. The founding fathers, Ms. Pelosi said at a news conference on Thursday morning, had fought for “a government of the many, not a government of the money.” Democrats, she said, will not “unilaterally disarm.”

articles.headline: Affluent Wine Buyers in Asia Find Their Confidence
articles.snippet: An adventurous and increasingly educated crowd is fueling a boom in fine wines in China and elsewhere in Asia, though prices have come down.
articles.abstract: An adventurous and increasingly educated crowd is fueling a boom in fine wines in China and elsewhere in Asia, though prices have come down.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Six bottles of 1990 Romanée-Conti Burgundy sold to an Asian buyer at a Christie’s auction in Hong Kong last month for 980,000 Hong Kong dollars ($126,345). A case of wine from the Cros Parantoux vineyard in Burgundy, France, fetched $82,333 in a sale held by the American auction house Acker Merrall & Condit at a restaurant overlooking Hong Kong’s harbor.

articles.headline: Sign of Spring on Pay: Real Wage Growth
articles.snippet: Years after the recession, there are now signs that the labor market is tightening enough that more workers may get raises that significantly exceed inflation.
articles.abstract: Years after the recession, there are now signs that the labor market is tightening enough that more workers may get raises that significantly exceed inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Dworkin, a Dallas builder, was surprised to find someone he didn’t recognize inside a half-finished house this winter where crews were about to texture the home’s drywall.

articles.headline: Personality and Change Inflamed Mozilla Crisis
articles.snippet: The issues troubling Mozilla, a highly unusual tech titan, run deeper than the firestorm that led to the departure of its chief, Brendan Eich, after only two weeks.
articles.abstract: The issues troubling Mozilla, a highly unusual tech titan, run deeper than the firestorm that led to the departure of its chief, Brendan Eich, after only two weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mozilla is not your typical Silicon Valley company.
articles.byline: By Quentin Hardy and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Afghan Turnout Is High as Voters Defy the Taliban
articles.snippet: The election will mark the first time Afghans have changed their leader at the polls in modern history as Hamid Karzai’s dozen years in power end.
articles.abstract: The election will mark the first time Afghans have changed their leader at the polls in modern history as Hamid Karzai’s dozen years in power end.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Defying a campaign of Taliban violence that unleashed 39 suicide bombers in the two months before Election Day, Afghan voters on Saturday turned out in such high numbers to choose a new president and provincial councils that polling hours were extended nationwide, in a triumph of determination over intimidation.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland, Azam Ahmed and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Minding the Minders of G.M.
articles.snippet: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is facing questions over its handling of the General Motors scandal involving defective ignition switches.
articles.abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is facing questions over its handling of the General Motors scandal involving defective ignition switches.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a truism in Washington that was confirmed last week in Congress: Even less popular than government regulation is a regulator suspected of not doing its job.

articles.headline: The Wallet as Ethics Enforcer
articles.snippet: Take back executives’ bonuses? It’s not likely to happen at G.M., or at many other companies, under current rules.
articles.abstract: Take back executives’ bonuses? It’s not likely to happen at G.M., or at many other companies, under current rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a lot we don’t yet know about the disastrous decisions made by General Motors after it became aware of faulty ignition switches in its Chevrolet Cobalts more than 10 years ago.

articles.headline: War Pain Yields to New Anxiety Inside Ft. Hood
articles.snippet: The number of soldiers at Fort Hood has fallen, and as the Army moves away from wartime footing, those who planned to make a career in the military face an uncertain path.
articles.abstract: The number of soldiers at Fort Hood has fallen, and as the Army moves away from wartime footing, those who planned to make a career in the military face an uncertain path.
articles.lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — Pastor Randall Wallace of the First Baptist Church of Killeen has watched thousands of troops head off to war and then come home to Fort Hood, the mammoth military base that shares this patch of Central Texas with an unpretentious jumble of pawn shops, fast food joints and vinyl-sided bungalows.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Serge F. Kovaleski and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Technology’s Man Problem
articles.snippet: Crude apps, patronizing behavior. For some, “bro” culture offers one explanation for why there are so few women in tech.
articles.abstract: Crude apps, patronizing behavior. For some, “bro” culture offers one explanation for why there are so few women in tech.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elissa Shevinsky can pinpoint the moment when she felt that she no longer belonged.

articles.headline: Civil Rights Sins, Curated by One of the Sinners
articles.snippet: Mississippi officials hope a publicly operated civil rights museum scheduled to open in 2017 will be a symbol that the state is reckoning with the ugliest parts of its history.
articles.abstract: Mississippi officials hope a publicly operated civil rights museum scheduled to open in 2017 will be a symbol that the state is reckoning with the ugliest parts of its history.
articles.lead_paragraph: HATTIESBURG, Miss. — In the woods off Monroe Road, a truck is so rusted that it is melting into the earth. It was Vernon Dahmer’s truck, the one that he drove and that his family continued to use after his death, the circumstances of which can be inferred from the three penny-size holes in the back panel.

articles.headline: Delays in Effort to Refocus C.I.A. From Drone War
articles.snippet: Despite avowals about the need to refocus the agency on its original missions of analysis, intelligence collecting and espionage, the paramilitary operations have proven hard to give up.
articles.abstract: Despite avowals about the need to refocus the agency on its original missions of analysis, intelligence collecting and espionage, the paramilitary operations have proven hard to give up.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the skies above Yemen, the Pentagon’s armed drones have stopped flying, a result of the ban on American military drone strikes imposed by the government there after a number of botched operations in recent years killed Yemeni civilians. But the Central Intelligence Agency’s drone war in Yemen continues.

articles.headline: Vox Takes Melding of Journalism and Technology to a New Level
articles.snippet: The new site, led by Ezra Klein, the founder of Wonkblog, features a next-generation content management tool that greatly enhances digital storytelling.
articles.abstract: The new site, led by Ezra Klein, the founder of Wonkblog, features a next-generation content management tool that greatly enhances digital storytelling.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ask Ezra Klein what prompted him to leave a high-profile position at The Washington Post to start a new website, and the answer is a little wonkish, even for the founder of the newspaper’s Wonkblog, a mix of politics, economics and domestic policy that had become must reading in the Beltway.

articles.headline: Questions for Comcast as It Looks to Grow
articles.snippet: As the company prepares to defend its proposed merger with Time Warner Cable at a Senate hearing this week, some obvious questions require answers.
articles.abstract: As the company prepares to defend its proposed merger with Time Warner Cable at a Senate hearing this week, some obvious questions require answers.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is hard to say how rugged the questions will be when Comcast goes before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday to defend its proposed megamerger with Time Warner Cable.

articles.headline: U.S. Tries Candor to Assure China on Cyberattacks
articles.snippet: The U.S. held an unusual briefing for China on its cyberwarfare strategy in an effort to establish “an understanding of rules of the road.” So far, the Chinese have not reciprocated.
articles.abstract: The U.S. held an unusual briefing for China on its cyberwarfare strategy in an effort to establish “an understanding of rules of the road.” So far, the Chinese have not reciprocated.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the months before Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s arrival in Beijing on Monday, the Obama administration quietly held an extraordinary briefing for the Chinese military leadership on a subject officials have rarely discussed in public: the Pentagon’s emerging doctrine for defending against cyberattacks against the United States — and for using its cybertechnology against adversaries, including the Chinese.

articles.headline: More Deportations Follow Minor Crimes, Records Show
articles.snippet: Two-thirds of the nearly two million people deported since President Obama took office had committed only minor infractions or had no criminal record, a New York Times analysis has found.
articles.abstract: Two-thirds of the nearly two million people deported since President Obama took office had committed only minor infractions or had no criminal record, a New York Times analysis has found.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the Obama administration deporting illegal immigrants at a record pace, the president has said the government is going after “criminals, gang bangers, people who are hurting the community, not after students, not after folks who are here just because they’re trying to figure out how to feed their families.”
articles.byline: By Ginger Thompson and Sarah Cohen

articles.headline: Cities Advance Their Fight Against Rising Inequality
articles.snippet: Cities across the country are considering proposals to tackle income inequality, but experts say localities have little control over the policy tools that could make the biggest impact.
articles.abstract: Cities across the country are considering proposals to tackle income inequality, but experts say localities have little control over the policy tools that could make the biggest impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In January, Teresa Fuentes’s employer told her she could work no more than 30 hours a week preparing burgers and passing out food at the drive-through for about $9.50 an hour.

articles.headline: Credit Suisse Is Said to Be Facing Double-Barreled Inquiries
articles.snippet: As Credit Suisse negotiates with the Justice Department over its liability for involvement in tax shelters, New York State has opened its own inquiry.
articles.abstract: As Credit Suisse negotiates with the Justice Department over its liability for involvement in tax shelters, New York State has opened its own inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of false starts and stops, the Justice Department is nearing the end of an investigation into the role Credit Suisse played in hiding American wealth offshore. But at the same time, a new investigation is beginning, threatening to entangle the giant Swiss bank for even longer.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: ‘Reverse Auctions’ Draw Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Supporters say FedBid and similar companies encourage competition, but critics say they prompt businesses to submit unrealistically low bids to shut out rivals.
articles.abstract: Supporters say FedBid and similar companies encourage competition, but critics say they prompt businesses to submit unrealistically low bids to shut out rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is like an eBay of Washington, a well-appointed and well-connected online marketplace for lucrative government contracts.

articles.headline: Facing His Torturer as Spain Confronts Its Past
articles.snippet: José María Galante says he was tortured by an infamous enforcer of the Franco dictatorship in the 1970s. He is seeking to prosecute the man in an Argentine court.
articles.abstract: José María Galante says he was tortured by an infamous enforcer of the Franco dictatorship in the 1970s. He is seeking to prosecute the man in an Argentine court.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — José María Galante was a leftist college student when he was handcuffed to the ceiling of a basement torture chamber, his body dangling in the air. A police inspector laughed and taunted him, striking martial arts poses before repeatedly kicking and beating his face and chest.

articles.headline: Gravity Hits Highflying Tech Stocks
articles.snippet: A turnaround for highflying tech and biotech stocks like Tesla, NXP Semiconductor and Alexion signals a potential shift that the time to chase eye-popping growth may be over.
articles.abstract: A turnaround for highflying tech and biotech stocks like Tesla, NXP Semiconductor and Alexion signals a potential shift that the time to chase eye-popping growth may be over.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of the past year, Tesla Motors seemingly could do no wrong in investors’ eyes.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: In East Ukraine, Protesters Seek Russian Troops
articles.snippet: Pro-Russian demonstrators occupying a government building in Donetsk also demanded a referendum on seceding from Ukraine, hours after a Ukrainian officer was killed in Crimea.
articles.abstract: Pro-Russian demonstrators occupying a government building in Donetsk also demanded a referendum on seceding from Ukraine, hours after a Ukrainian officer was killed in Crimea.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Under the attentive eye of Russian state television, several hundred pro-Russian demonstrators in the city of Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine, declared on Monday that they were forming an independent republic and urged President Vladimir V. Putin to send troops to the region as a peacekeeping force, even though there was no imminent threat to peace.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Andrew Roth

articles.headline: Tax Preparers Targeting Poor With High Fees
articles.snippet: Tax season brings the biggest one-time influx of money many Americans see all year, but it also attracts unscrupulous preparers.
articles.abstract: Tax season brings the biggest one-time influx of money many Americans see all year, but it also attracts unscrupulous preparers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — In December, they begin showing up in empty storefronts in neighborhoods where empty storefronts are easy to come by. Cars with phone numbers brightly displayed on the doors roll down the streets, and signs pop up along the sidewalks promising fast money.
